Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Automated and community-driven synthesis of the tree of life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tree of life links all biodiversity through a shared evolutionary history. This project will produce the first online, comprehensive first-draft tree of all 1.8 million named species, accessible to both the public and scientific communities. Assembly of the tree will incorporate previously published results, with strong collaborations between computational and empirical biologists to develop, test and improve methods of data synthesis. This initial tree of life will not be static; instead, we will develop tools for scientists to update and revise the tree as new data come in. Early release of the tree and tools will motivate data sharing and facilitate ongoing synthesis of knowledge.

Biological research of all kinds, including studies of ecological health, environmental change, and human disease, increasingly depends on knowing how species are related to each other. Yet there is no single resource that unites knowledge of the tree of life. Instead, only small parts of the tree are individually available, generally as printed figures in journal articles. This project will provide the global community of scientists who study the tree of life with a means to share and combine their results, and will enable large-scale studies of Earth's biodiversity. It will also create a resource where students, educators and citizens can go to explore and learn about life's evolutionary history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Open Tree of Life project is to construct a comprehensive view of the evolutionary tree for all life on Earth. An evolutionary tree depicts the pattern of ancestry that connects all living species to each other. Many relationships have been estimated covering parts of the "Tree of Life." The Open Tree of Life project stitches these estimates together into one comprehensive view. The project lets biologists find where different published studies disagree about the evolutionary relationships of the same species. That is helpful in identifying contexts where more research is needed.
The award to the University of Kansas funded work on the three main parts of the project: the development of a database of published trees, the development of the methods and software for creating the comprehensive tree, and the implementation of software to make the project's products accessible as web services.
The database of published trees stores information about published evolutionary studies and makes the published trees more useful by standardizing the names of species used in different studies. The database of published studies is crucial to the Open Tree of Life project because it provides the input data for the comprehensive tree. The database is available to other researchers, as well. Other projects in the field of bioinformatics make use of the Open Tree of Life database of published trees to accomplish their goals. So, this portion of the project has become an important piece of infrastructure for comparative biology.
This award also funded the development of the methods and software that the project uses to build the comprehensive tree from the input trees. Building a comprehensive estimate of evolutionary relationships from previous smaller estimates is called "supertree" estimation. While the idea of supertree estimation is not new, the Open Tree of Life project had to build a supertree with a much larger number of species compared to prior work. New algorithms were designed and implemented into optimized software. The software can build the tree in less than an hour; this allows the Open Tree of Life project to be updated as new studies are published.
Finally, the award was used to design and write software that provides web services. The Open Tree of Life project publishes the database of curated trees or the comprehensive trees as files that can be downloaded by anyone. In addition to those downloads, the project also built software that allows any software developer to search for and view portions of the comprehensive tree or the input trees. These views of the data and estimates are provided via a commonly used technology called web services. Other bioinformatic projects use the Open Tree of Life web services, and the web services are used by the Open Tree of Life's own web site. Visitors to the Open Tree of Life project web site (https://tree.opentreeoflife.org) interact with "front-end" web pages and code that was primarily written by our collaborators at Duke University (funded by a linked collaborative NSF award). The front-end parts of the web site have to request data from the web services. Most of those web services were written by researchers funded by the award to the University of Kansas.
